metadata.titleEn: B-Mo isotopic data set of ore bearing adakitic rocks in central and eastern China
metadata.description: The data in this paper include some major and trace elements, whole rock SR – nd and B-Mo isotopic data of adakitic rocks. The samples were collected from Dexing porphyry deposit in Jiangxi Province, central and eastern China, and Shaxi, Tongshankou and fengshandong porphyry deposits in the middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze River. The lithology includes granodiorite porphyry and quartz diorite porphyry. B-Mo isotope data were determined by multi collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (MC – ICP – MS). Based on the B-Mo isotopic data, combined with the element and Sr Nd isotopic data obtained by predecessors, the genesis of ore bearing adakitic rocks can be defined, and the mineralization mechanism of porphyry can be enlightened.
metadata.instructions: The data are stored in Excel file, in which ada-bmo.xsl represents the B-Mo isotopic analysis data of adakitic rocks

authorList.unitEn: Guangzhou Institute of Geochemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences

literatureList.titleEn: B-Mo isotope dataset of mineralized adakitic rocks in central and eastern China
literatureList.referenceEn: Fan, J. J., Wang, Q.， Li, J., Wei, G. J., Derek, W., Zhao, Z. H., Liu, Y., Ma, J. L., Zhang, L., & Wang, Z. L. (2020). Molybdenum and Boron isotopic compositions of porphyry Cu mineralization-related adakitic rocks in central-eastern China: New insights into their petrogenesis and crust-mantle interaction. Journal of Geophysics Research: Solid Earth, 125. https://doi.org/10.1029/2020JB020474.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used for analyzing B-Mo isotopes in mineral-bearing adakitic rocks?
Example.Answer: A data collection method for analyzing B-Mo isotopes in mineral-bearing adakitic rocks involves using multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (MC–ICP–MS).

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific methods used to analyze B-Mo isotopes in mineral-bearing adakitic rocks, and how do these methods contribute to understanding the rocks' genesis and mineralization processes?
Feature Specification.Answer: multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (MC–ICP–MS), precise measurement of isotopic ratios

Definition.Question: What does 'B-Mo isotope data' mean in the context of adakite rocks?
Definition.Answer: B-Mo isotope data refers to the analysis of boron (B) and molybdenum (Mo) isotopes obtained from adakite rocks, which are used to understand the genesis of mineralized adakitic rocks and provide insights into porphyry mineralization mechanisms.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors may influence the accuracy of B-Mo isotope data collection using multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry in the analysis of mineralized adakitic rocks from China's central and eastern regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The accuracy of B-Mo isotope data collection using multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (MC–ICP–MS) can be influenced by several factors, including the precision of sample preparation, the calibration of the mass spectrometer, potential contamination during sample handling, and the inherent isotopic composition variability within the mineralized adakitic rocks. These rocks are sourced from complex geological settings such as the Dexing porphyry deposit in Jiangxi and various locations along the middle and lower Yangtze River areas, which may also contribute to data variability.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the likely outcomes in understanding the genesis of mineralized adakite-like rocks when employing B-Mo isotope data collection methods combined with previous elemental and Sr-Nd isotope data?
Causal Consequence.Answer: By using B-Mo isotope data collection methods along with previously obtained elemental and Sr-Nd isotope data, researchers can potentially better define the genesis of mineralized adakite-like rocks. This comprehensive approach might provide insights into the porphyry mineralization mechanisms in regions such as the Jiangxi Dexing porphyry mining area and the mid-lower Yangtze River areas, enhancing our understanding of their formation processes and contributing to more effective exploration strategies.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals behind collecting B-Mo isotope data using MC–ICP–MS in the context of mineral-bearing adakitic rocks in central and eastern China?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goals are to define the genesis of mineral-bearing adakitic rocks and gain insights into the porphyry mineralization mechanisms by combining B-Mo isotope data with existing elemental and Sr-Nd isotope data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What instrumental and procedural methods are employed for collecting and analyzing B-Mo isotopic data in adakitic rocks to understand the mineralization processes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The instrumental method used for collecting and analyzing B-Mo isotopic data in adakitic rocks involves the use of multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (MC–ICP–MS). This technique allows for precise isotopic measurements, which are critical in understanding the genesis of mineral-bearing adakitic rocks. The data is further combined with previously obtained major and trace element data, as well as whole-rock Sr-Nd isotopic data, to draw insights into the formation mechanisms and mineralization processes of the porphyry deposits in regions such as the Jiangxi Dexing and the middle-lower reaches of the Yangtze River. The samples include various lithologies such as granodioritic porphyry and quartz dioritic porphyry.
